subtitles.transcript: I think the way that conversation about out of state, in state has been set up in the sort of public narrative
is sort of an artificial binary that, “Well, we need to do this to pay for the cost of sort of running the business here.”
I think that there are other ways to pay, right? And that’s not the thing we need to lean on.
There’s also this sense that if they want it bad enough and they’re paying for it, we’re not oppressing them —
that sort of thing. I think that’s a sort of simplistic and poor logic. You know, those people are also our neighbors,
and are we going to screw them over in the process like, “Sure, you can come here and eat at my house.
Don’t forget to bring the food.” You know? “Otherwise, you’re not eating.” You know, that sort of thing?
It’s sort of a little … like that is poor form, you know? Like that’s not how you treat people.
